heading: 3.1 Getting Started
text: Hopefully, already experiences plotting basic R graphics. Chapter, briefly introduced one powerful plotting packages R: ggplot2 ’s basic grammar functions.

heading: 3.2 Default Part: Layer
text: Unlike graphics packages, one remarkable advantages ggplot2 underlying grammar enables compose graphs combining different components. can easily create novel graphics adding ggplot2 functions meet needs based data.definition grammar graphics, important features data mapping layers ’s getting started.plots composed data, information want visualize, mapping, description data’s variables mapped aesthetic attributes. data independent elements, layered graphic can built utilizes different data sources keeping components . say, can add several layers ggplot.
code:
library(ggplot2)
library(datasets)

# Using 'iris' in 'datasets' library as data
ggplot(data = datasets::iris) +  #Data part
  geom_point(aes(Sepal.Length, Sepal.Width))  #Mapping part
ggplot(data = datasets::iris) +  #Data part
  geom_point(aes(Petal.Length, Petal.Width)) +  #layer 1 with mapping 
  geom_point(aes(Sepal.Length, Sepal.Width), color='red')  #layer 2 with a different mapping

heading: 3.3.1 Geometric object, Statistical transformation and Position adjustment
text: Geometric object, Statistical transformation Position adjustment components can customized layer.Geometric objects geoms control type plot create. geom can display certain aesthetics visual attributes geom. example, point geom position, color, shape, size aesthetics. first decide kind plot better explains data choosing geoms use help function check aesthetics can modified achieve desired effects.statistical transformation stat transforms data, generally summarizing information. Position adjustment applied need adjust position elements plot dense data, otherwise data points might obscure one another.

heading: 3.3.2 Scale
text: scale controls data mapped aesthetic attributes, usually one scale every aesthetic property employed layer.
code:
ggplot(data = datasets::iris) + 
  geom_histogram(mapping=aes(x=Petal.Length, fill=Species), stat = 'bin',position = 'stack')+
  scale_x_continuous(limits = c(0, 10)) +
  scale_y_continuous(limits = c(0, 50))

heading: 3.3.3 Coordinate system
text: coordinate system coord maps position objects onto plane plot, controls axes grid lines drawn. One ggplot can one coord

heading: 3.3.4 Faceting
text: Faceting can used split data subsets entire dataset.

heading: 3.3.5 Labels
text: Labels include titles, labels x,y axis annotates. Good graphics also need give clear information using labels tell readers’ background knowledge data.
code:
ggplot(data = datasets::iris) + 
  geom_histogram(mapping=aes(x=Petal.Length, fill=Species), 
                 stat = 'bin',position = 'stack')+
  ggtitle('Stacked Histogram on Petal Length of Different Species') +
  xlab('Length of Petal')

heading: 3.4 ggplot2 Resources
text: implementations examples, one easiest way referring ggplot2 Cheatsheets provided R. Follow steps shown can find cheat-sheets RStudio.cheat-sheets clearly list basic components ggplot can customize unique plot choosing different functions.seeking detailed explanations examples real datasets, useful links : ggplot2: Elegant Graphics

heading: 4 Unidimensional Continuous Variables
text: chapter, demonstrate graphs unidimensional continuous variables using ggplot2.

heading: 4.1.1 Basics and implications
text: start easy example.example, used geom_histogram create histogram variable x. can see quick make need much pre-processing. Moreover, Histograms show data’s empirical distribution within set intervals suggest using one first steps understand data.Note: shown , ggplot expects dataframe, make sure throw vector ggplot.
code:
library(ggplot2)
library(gridExtra)

#Example data
x <- c(50, 51, 53, 55, 56, 60, 65, 65, 68)
#Stored as a dataframe
df <- data.frame(x)

ggplot(df, aes(x)) +
  geom_histogram(color = "blue", fill = "lightBlue", 
                 binwidth = 5, center = 52.5) +
  ggtitle("ggplot2 histogram of x")

heading: 4.1.2 Types of Histograms
text: y-scale histograms can represented variety ways express different results:Frequency count: y = number values fall binRelative frequency: y = number values fall bin / total number valuesCumulative frequency: y = total number values <= (<) right boundary binDensity: y = relative frequency / binwidth

heading: 4.1.3.1 Bin boundaries
text: mindful boundaries bins whether point fall left right bin boundary. can use parameter closed control intervals.
code:
p1 <- ggplot(df, aes(x)) +
  geom_histogram(color="blue",fill="lightblue", 
                 binwidth = 5, center = 52.5, closed="left")  +
  ggtitle("Left Closed graph")

p2 <- ggplot(df, aes(x)) +
  geom_histogram(color="blue",fill="lightblue", 
                 binwidth = 5, center = 52.5, closed="right")  +
  ggtitle("Right Closed graph")

grid.arrange(p1, p2, ncol = 2)

heading: 4.1.3.2 Bin numbers
text:
start passing parameters geom_histogram notice pop-saying default number bins 30.
see graph ideal gaps. two ways modify number bins: specify width explicitly binwidth provide desired number bins bins. Consider following modifications:Note: gold standard number bins, try different numbers generate best results.
code:
library(Sleuth3)
finches <- Sleuth3::case0201

#Default / Only adding some styles to make graph consistent
ggplot(finches, aes(x = Depth)) +
  geom_histogram(color="blue",fill="lightblue") +
  ggtitle("Default with pop-up about bin number")
# using binwidth
p3 <- ggplot(finches, aes(x = Depth)) +
  geom_histogram(color="blue",fill="lightblue",
                 binwidth = 0.5, boundary = 6) +
  ggtitle("Changed binwidth value")

# using bins
p4 <- ggplot(finches, aes(x = Depth)) +
  geom_histogram(color="blue",fill="lightblue",
                 bins = 15, boundary = 6) +
  ggtitle("Changed bin value")

# format plot layout
grid.arrange(p3, p4, ncol = 2)

heading: 4.1.3.3 Bin alignment
text: Consider comparisonNotice boundary bins start axis difference code removal boundry. control position bins, can use either parameter center boundary. can use boundary specify endpoint bin center specify center bin ggplot2 able calculate place rest bins. (Also, notice boundary changed, number bins got smaller one. default bins centered go /range data.) example, specify boundary 6. can see first bin starts 6 position bins calculated based binwidth 0.5.
code:
p5 <- ggplot(finches, aes(x = Depth)) +
  geom_histogram(color="blue",fill="lightblue",binwidth = 0.5) +
  ggtitle("Without alignment")

p6 <- ggplot(finches, aes(x = Depth)) +
  geom_histogram(color="blue",fill="lightblue",bins = 15, boundary = 6) +
  ggtitle("With alignment")

grid.arrange(p5, p6, ncol = 2)

heading: 4.1.4 Interactive histograms with ggvis
text: ggvis package currently development, certain things well, adjusting parameters histogram interactively coding. interested, refer .

heading: 4.2.1 Single Boxplot
text: boxplot one simplest ways representing distribution continuous variable (Never use boxplots categorical data). consists two parts: box whiskers. Let’s starting simple example: single boxplot.can see, boxplots provide ton information single chart. Boxplots tell whether variable normally distributed, distribution skewed either direction. can also easily spot outliers, always helps.
code:
library(datasets)
ggplot(Orange, aes(x=circumference))+
  geom_boxplot()+
  ggtitle("Boxplot of circumference")

heading: 4.2.2 Multiple boxplots
text: Next, want compare distributions multiple classes? , can create multiple boxplot. remember, data frame needs tidy, need column levels grouping variable. can factor, character, integer class.following example still use Orange dataset. compare distributions circumference different Tree(indicates tree types ordering max diameter).Note. Usually boxplot, boxes reordered decreasing order class medians left right.Often want boxplots horizontal. Super easy ggplot2: just tack + coord_flip() remove - reordering factor level highest median top:
code:
ggplot(Orange, aes(x=reorder(Tree, -circumference, median),y=circumference))+
  geom_boxplot()+
  ggtitle("Multiple boxplots of circumference of different types of Trees")+
  labs(y="Circumference at Breast Height", x="Tree with ordering of max diameter")
ggplot(Orange, aes(x=reorder(Tree, circumference, median),y=circumference))+
  geom_boxplot()+ 
  coord_flip()+
  ggtitle("Multiple boxplots of circumference of different types of Trees")+
  labs(y="Circumference at Breast Height", x="Tree with ordering of max diameter")

heading: 4.3.1 Basics and implications
text: Ridgeline plots can used number data segments plotted horizontal scale. presented slight overlap. Ridgeline plots useful visualize distribution categorical variable time space.good example using ridgeline plots great example visualizing distribution salary different departments company.Consider following example:ggridge uses two main geoms plot ridgeline density plots: geom_density_ridges geom_ridgeline. used plot densities categorical variable factors see distribution continuous scale.
code:
library(ggridges)
library(forcats)

ggplot(Orange, aes(x=circumference,y=fct_rev(fct_inorder(Tree)),fill = fct_inorder(Tree))) +
  geom_density_ridges() +
  scale_fill_brewer(palette = 4) +
  scale_y_discrete(expand = c(0.8, 0)) +
  scale_x_continuous(expand = c(0.01, 0)) +
  ggtitle("Density estimation of circumference of different types of Trees") +
  labs(x="Circumference at Breast Height", y="Tree with ordering of max diameter") +
  theme_ridges() +
  theme(plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.5), axis.title.x = element_text(hjust=0.5), legend.title = element_blank())

heading: 4.3.2 Create better visuals
text: example, added parameter scale alpha control overlaps ridges. Scale defines much peak lower curve touches curve alpha controls transparency.
code:
ggplot(Orange, aes(x=circumference,y=fct_rev(fct_inorder(Tree)),fill = fct_inorder(Tree))) +
  geom_density_ridges(scale = 2, alpha=0.5) +
  scale_fill_brewer(palette = 4) +
  scale_y_discrete(expand = c(0.8, 0)) +
  scale_x_continuous(expand = c(0.01, 0)) +
  ggtitle("Density estimation of circumference of different types of Trees") +
  labs(x="Circumference at Breast Height", y="Tree with ordering of max diameter") +
  theme_ridges() +
  theme(plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.5), axis.title.x = element_text(hjust=0.5), legend.title = element_blank())

heading: 4.4 Normal Distribution
text: encountering data seems normally distributed, may want overlay normal curve.many ways draw normal curve introduce one hereNotice normal curve compatiable facet. Consider following exampleAs might notice, even though normal curve appears sections, actually one generated whole dataset. circumstance, suggest drawing graph separately combine .
code:
ggplot(finches, aes(x = Depth)) +
  geom_histogram(aes(y=..density..),color="blue",fill="lightblue",
                 binwidth = 0.5) +
  stat_function(fun=dnorm, col = "red",
                args=list(mean(finches$Depth),sd(finches$Depth)))+
  ggtitle("Normal curve overlaid")
